title: Mendelian randomization study of adiposity-related traits and risk of breast, ovarian, prostate, lung and colorectal cancer
author: Gao
author_address: Program in Genetic Epidemiology and Statistical Genetics, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA,
hypothesis: Effect of birthweight, childhood and adult body mass index, and waist-hip ratio on the risks of breast, ovarian, prostate, colorectal and lung cancer
rationale: Adiposity traits have been associated with risk of many cancers in observational studies, but whether these associations are causal is unclear.
limitations_overall: Discuss several: MR assumptions, limits of summary level approach, limited power
limitations_pleiotropy: To test for and correct for bias due to pleiotropy where the InSIDE assumption holds, we performed Egger regression for all traits investigated
limitations_population_stratification: population stratification may be a source of confounding but the original studies saw little evidence for such bias and all have appropriately controlled for it.
limitations_statistical_power: Finally, the statistical power is limited by both the proportion of the adiposity risk factors explained by the genetic instruments, and the sample size in the cancer genetic association studies
notes: Repeated analysis after removing overlapping loci, same results

title: The association between weight at birth and breast cancer risk revisited using Mendelian randomisation
author: Kar
author_address: Department of Public Health and Primary Care, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK
hypothesis: Effect of birth weight on breast cancer risk
rationale: Observational studies suggest that higher birth weight is associated with increased risk of breast cancer in adult life
outcome_study: Michailidou  2017 Breast Cancer  European and East Asian  female
exposure_pleiotropy: Took 41 of the 49 SNPs that were not associated with birth length, adult height, adult BMI, age at menarche, age at menopause, age at first birth, number of children ever born at P < 5x10-8
exposure_proxy: 26 SNPs, proxy SNPs in linkage disequilibrium with the BW-associ- ated lead SNP (r2 > 0.6 in European samples)
n_SNP_difference_reason: Took 41 of the 49 SNPs that were not associated with birth length, adult height, adult BMI, age at menarche, age at menopause, age at first birth, number of children ever born at P < 5x10-8
power_calculation_how: A priori power to detect an association at a significance level of 0.05 was calculated using an online tool (https://sb452.shinyapps.io/power)
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Consistent with main analysis - Sensitivity analyses using four alternative methods and three alternative IVs, including an IV with 59 of the 60 BW-associated SNPs, yielded similar results.
limitations_overall: lack of strong associations between the other birth weight SNPs and age at first birth and number of children ever born, not being able to adjust for these two putative breast cancer risk factors in our multivariable MR is highly unlikely to have substantially altered the overall conclusion from our MR study.
limitations_pleiotropy: The BW-associated lead SNP at the 41 loci did not show genome-wide significant pleiotropic associations
limitations_population_stratification: Data on the association between BW and breast cancer risk in non-European populations is scarce
limitations_statistical_power: Genetic IV with maximum power (59-SNP IV) explained only 2% of the variance of BW, Horikoshi et al. study excluded individuals with extremes of BW (for the UK Biobank, which contributed nearly half the European sample, this was defined as < 2500 g or > 4000 g). Thus, the genetic IV we used may not adequately capture common genetic variants that only specifically affect the extremes of BW
